[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: GetDefaultUserFeeController()] [Three-Tier Complexity] The UserFeeController has three levels (Parliament -> Referendum -> Association) - does this complexity increase attack surface by requiring three separate organization validations? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: GetDefaultUserFeeController()] [Empty Object Anti-Pattern] Lines 334-339 create empty AuthorityInfo objects immediately overwritten - is this pattern used consistently across the codebase or just in this function? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: GetDefaultSymbolToPayTxFeeController()] [Single Line Function] Line 356 simply returns GetDefaultParliamentController() - does this indirection serve any purpose or could it lead to confusion about which controller actually manages symbol fee settings? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: GetDefaultSymbolToPayTxFeeController()] [No Caching] Unlike other controller getters, this function doesn't cache the result in state - will repeated calls cause unnecessary external contract calls to Parliament? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: GetDefaultSideChainRentalController()] [State.SideChainCreator Dependency] Line 366 uses State.SideChainCreator.Value without null check - if this value is not set before calling GetDefaultSideChainRentalController(), will CalculateOrganizationAddress() return an incorrect address? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: GetDefaultSideChainRentalController()] [Association Contract Reuse] Lines 361-363 initialize State.AssociationContract.Value again even though it may already be set - is this defensive programming or inefficient? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: GetDefaultSideChainRentalController()] [Creator Manipulation] If an attacker can set State.SideChainCreator.Value before this function is called, can they control the calculated rental controller address and subsequently control rental pricing? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: GetTransferBlackListController()] [Null Default] Lines 378-379 return GetDefaultParliamentController() if State.TransferBlackListController.Value is null - does this mean parliament has blacklist power by default before explicit controller initialization? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: GetTransferBlackListController()] [No Initialization Check] Unlike other controllers, TransferBlackListController doesn't have explicit initialization in InitializeAuthorizedController() - can it be in an undefined state until ChangeTransferBlackListController() is called? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: AssertDeveloperFeeController()] [Null Check Only] Lines 385-386 only check if State.DeveloperFeeController.Value is null but don't verify the controller structure is valid (RootController, ParliamentController, DeveloperController are non-null) - can partially initialized controllers pass this check? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: AssertDeveloperFeeController()] [Context.Sender Check] Line 388 checks Context.Sender == State.DeveloperFeeController.Value.RootController.OwnerAddress - if RootController is null or has null OwnerAddress after ChangeD developerController() nullifies sub-controllers, will this cause null reference exception? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: AssertDeveloperFeeController()] [Generic Error Message] The error message 'no permission' at line 388 doesn't indicate which controller or operation was attempted - can this ambiguity make auditing and debugging harder? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Method_Authorization.cs] [Function: AssertDeveloperFeeController()] [Single Point Check] The function only checks RootController ownership, not whether RootController itself is a valid organization with appropriate thresholds - can a trivial organization pass this check?
